children.definition: Which transfer mechanisms are blocked: RPs only, investments only, or all means including 'or otherwise' language.
children.name: Transfer Scope

children.definition: Sub-component addressing whether the J.Crew IP transfer blocker covers restricted payment transactions that move material intellectual property or assets to unrestricted subsidiaries through dividend or distribution mechanisms.
children.name: Applies to RPs

children.definition: Sub-component addressing whether the J.Crew IP transfer blocker covers investment transactions that move material intellectual property or assets to unrestricted subsidiaries through permitted investment baskets.
children.name: Applies to Investments

children.definition: Whether the IP transfer block includes catch-all 'or otherwise' language covering transfer mechanisms beyond RPs and investments.
children.name: Applies to Other Means
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 84 (Unknown); KCT Cat 1 Item 2

children.definition: Prohibits transfer of Material IP to unrestricted subsidiaries through any means including RPs, investments, or otherwise.
children.name: IP Transfer Block

children.definition: Whether the credit agreement contains an explicit prohibition on designating IP-holding subsidiaries as unrestricted.
children.name: Designation Block Present

children.definition: Whether the designation block extends to equity interests in IP-holding entities, not just asset transfers.
children.name: Applies to Equity Interests
children.definition_source: Learning Material: Equity Interests in Unrestricted and Immaterial Subsidiaries

children.definition: Prohibits designation of IP-owning subsidiaries as unrestricted, preventing the indirect transfer of material IP outside the restricted group.
children.name: Designation Restriction

children.definition: Whether the definition covers only registered IP, all material IP, or extends to material assets broadly including revenue-generating assets.
children.name: Definition Breadth

children.definition: Whether the Material IP definition in the J.Crew blocker extends to exclusive licenses (not just owned IP), closing the loophole where a borrower could exclusively license rather than transfer IP to achieve the same economic effect.
children.name: Includes Exclusive Licenses

children.definition: The standard for determining materiality: 'material to the business,' quantitative threshold, or both.
children.name: Materiality Standard

children.definition: The defined scope of 'Material Intellectual Property' or 'Material Assets' that triggers the J.Crew blocker. Breadth of this definition determines blocker effectiveness.
children.name: Material IP Definition

children.definition: Whether the J.Crew protection covers both transfer prongs: (1) direct transfer of material IP to unrestricted subsidiaries and (2) designation of IP-holding subsidiaries as unrestricted. Both prongs required for comprehensive protection.
children.name: Both Prongs Covered

children.definition: Whether the blocker applies to transfers to nonguarantor restricted subsidiaries (not just unrestricted subs).
children.name: Extends to Nonguarantor Restricted Subs
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 8; LME Provision Language, J.Crew Protection Extends to All Nonguarantor Subsidiaries (Pluralsight)

children.definition: Whether the blocker covers both transfer and designation prongs, and whether it extends to nonguarantor restricted subs (Pluralsight enhancement).
children.name: Dual-Prong Coverage

children.definition: Carve-out permitting non-exclusive licensing of IP on arm's-length terms in the ordinary course. Standard market exception that preserves operational flexibility.
children.name: Non-Exclusive License Exception

children.definition: Restricts leakage of material IP and crown-jewel assets to unrestricted subsidiaries. LME Provision Language Protection #1: A J.Crew blocker should prohibit (a) any transfer of material intellectual property or other material assets through any means (restricted payments, investments or otherwise) to unrestricted subsidiaries; and (b) the designation of subsidiaries that own material intellectual property or other material assets as unrestricted subsidiaries. Common weaknesses: (a) weakness in definition of 'Material Intellectual Property' or 'Material Assets'; (b) missing either the designation or transfer prong; (c) blocker only applies to certain types of transfers (e.g., 'Permitted Investments' only, not restricted payments); (d) blocker only applies to transfers by loan parties but not by nonguarantor restricted subsidiaries. PC Term Comparison: 'J Crew protections standard. Correct any Trap Door provisions. Also get "non-exclusive" for licenses; try to block material IP transfers to non-guarantors if possible.'
children.name: J.Crew Blocker

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Broader permitted modifications; no operating lease restriction; no sub equity issuance restriction
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Anti-J.Crew: restrict IP transfers to unrestricted subsidiaries; prohibit designation of material IP-holding entities as unrestricted

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Investments – Investments in Unsubs/JVs

children.definition_source: LME Provision Language Protection #1 (J.Crew: complete definition, drafting considerations, 4 common weaknesses, sample clause from private CA); PC Term Comparison Investments section (J.Crew standard, correct trap door, non-exclusive licenses)

children.definition: Whether the credit agreement contains an explicit restriction preventing automatic guarantee release upon loss of wholly-owned status.
children.name: Restriction Present

children.definition: Whether the Chewy automatic guarantee release restriction applies to all guarantor subsidiaries, not just material or wholly-owned ones, preventing selective release of guarantees from high-value entities.
children.name: Applies to All Guarantors
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 3 Item 11; Review Template Row 40 (Collateral/Guarantor release – Chewy)

children.definition: Blocks guarantee release solely from ownership change below wholly-owned threshold. Guarantor remains obligated unless additional conditions met.
children.name: Auto-Release Restriction

children.definition: Whether the Chewy bona fide business purpose test relies solely on subjective management judgment without objective criteria, creating risk that the test provides insufficient protection against pretextual transactions.
children.name: Subjective Only

children.definition: Objective criteria within the bona fide purpose test for liability management exercises, requiring demonstrable business justification for the transaction beyond mere creditor-adverse restructuring. These conditions (minimum cash flow thresholds, arm's-length terms, independent valuation) prevent pretextual transfers designed primarily to move assets beyond the reach of existing creditors.
children.name: Objective Conditions

children.definition: Requires that the minority equity transfer have a genuine business purpose, not merely a mechanism to achieve guarantee release.
children.name: Bona Fide Business Purpose Test

children.definition: Requires the equity transferee to be a non-affiliated third party, preventing sponsor-orchestrated minority transfers.
children.name: Non-Affiliated Transferee Requirement

children.definition: Whether guarantee release can still be obtained through the investment covenant, bypassing the Chewy blocker. Cross-covenant coordination gap.
children.name: Investment Covenant Coordination

children.definition: Coordination with J.Crew: guarantee cannot be released if the entity holds material IP or assets, regardless of ownership change.
children.name: Material Asset Link
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 2; LME Provision Language, Restrictions on Material Intellectual Property or Other Asset Leakage to Unsubs (J.Crew)

children.definition: Protection restricting the automatic release of a subsidiary guarantor that ceases to be a wholly-owned subsidiary following a partial transfer of the subsidiary's equity (LME Protection #2). Per the LME Provision Language, a Chewy blocker should prohibit automatic releases using a balanced mix of objective conditions (e.g., based on the transferee's identity) and subjective conditions (e.g., the purpose of the transaction). Exceptions should at least require the partial equity transfer to be: (a) to a non-affiliated third party; and (b) for a bona fide business purpose other than to obtain release of the guarantee. Common weaknesses: (a) provision predicated only on subjective factors; (b) release can still be obtained if treated as an investment in a nonguarantor restricted subsidiary permitted by the investment covenant. PC Term Comparison: typically include tighter formulation requiring investment capacity for FMV of released guarantor, sale of equity to a non-affiliate and/or bona fide business purpose, avoiding automatic release (require Agent action), and EoD stopper if foreign sub voluntarily guaranteed and seeks release.
children.name: Chewy Blocker

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Broader permitted modifications; no operating lease restriction; no sub equity issuance restriction
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Anti-Chewy: restrict dividend-recapture of collateral value to non-guarantor subsidiaries; cap RP capacity available for leakage

children.definition_source: LME Provision Language protection #2 (complete Chewy specification with sample clause from MillerKnoll April 2025 CA); PC Term Comparison neg covs Chewy section (5 tightening requirements)

children.definition: Whether the Pluralsight non-guarantor value leakage protection extends to restricted subsidiaries that are not loan parties, preventing asset transfers to restricted but non-guarantor entities.
children.name: Covers Nonguarantor Restricted

children.definition: Whether the Pluralsight non-guarantor value leakage protection extends to unrestricted subsidiaries, the primary vehicle for J.Crew-style drop-down transactions that move assets beyond lender reach.
children.name: Covers Unrestricted

children.definition: Whether the Pluralsight non-guarantor value leakage protection covers all non-loan-party entities comprehensively, including both restricted non-guarantors and unrestricted subsidiaries without gaps.
children.name: Covers All Non-Loan Parties
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 89 (Unknown); KCT Cat 1 Item 2; Learning Material: Non-Term Loan B Prepayment Premiums

children.definition: Whether the blocker extends protection to nonguarantor restricted subsidiaries in addition to unrestricted subsidiaries.
children.name: Nonguarantor Extension Scope

children.definition: Definition of 'Material Property' which is broader than Material IP, potentially covering all material assets of the restricted group.
children.name: Material Property Definition
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 2; LME Provision Language, Restrictions on Material Intellectual Property or Other Asset Leakage to Unsubs (J.Crew)

children.definition: Carveout from asset transfer restrictions permitting IP licensing arrangements, which was exploited in the Pluralsight liability management transaction to move valuable intellectual property assets to unrestricted subsidiaries through licensing structures. Post-Pluralsight credit agreements now address this vector by restricting exclusive licenses or requiring fair-market-value consideration.
children.name: Licensing Exception

children.definition: Covenant preventing unrestricted subsidiaries from acquiring or holding ownership interests in the borrower's core intellectual property assets, directly addressing the Pluralsight restructuring tactic. This prohibition closes the IP migration pathway by ensuring that operating IP remains within the restricted group and available as indirect collateral support.
children.name: Ownership Prohibition

children.definition: Enhanced version of J.Crew protection that extends the restriction on leakage of material assets (usually material intellectual property) to any nonguarantor subsidiary, including nonguarantor restricted subsidiaries -- not just unrestricted subsidiaries (LME Protection #3). Per the LME Provision Language, a Pluralsight blocker should prohibit: (a) any transfer of material intellectual property or other material assets through any means (restricted payments, investments or otherwise) by loan parties to non-loan parties (including unrestricted subs and nonguarantor restricted subs); and (b) non-loan parties from owning or exclusively licensing such material assets. Common weaknesses are similar to J.Crew blockers. Sample clause from AMC July 2024 CA uses 'Material Property' definition covering assets material to the business, operations, assets, or financial condition of the relevant group, taken as a whole.
children.name: Pluralsight Blocker

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Broader permitted modifications; no operating lease restriction; no sub equity issuance restriction
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Anti-PluralSight: prohibit exchange offers that create senior tranches from existing pari passu debt without all-lender consent

children.definition_source: LME Provision Language protection #3 (complete Pluralsight specification with sample clause from AMC July 2024 CA)

children.definition: Whether only specified investment baskets can fund unsub transfers (vs. any available basket capacity).
children.name: Specific Baskets Only

children.definition: Fixed dollar aggregate cap on total value that can be transferred to non-loan parties under the Envision basket limitation framework, constraining the cumulative magnitude of leakage transactions.
children.name: Aggregate Dollar Cap

children.definition: EBITDA-based percentage cap on total unsub investment capacity, typically as greater-of with dollar amount.
children.name: Aggregate EBITDA Percentage Cap

children.definition: Restricts which investment baskets can be used to fund unsub transfers, limiting access to specific or aggregate-capped baskets.
children.name: Basket Limitation

children.definition: Whether the Envision transfer means protection covers investment transactions as a channel for moving assets to non-loan parties, parallel to the investment covenant's permitted basket structure.
children.name: Applies to Investments

children.definition: Whether the Envision transfer means protection covers restricted payment transactions as a channel for distributing value to non-loan parties through dividend or distribution mechanisms.
children.name: Applies to RPs

children.definition: Whether the Envision cap applies to transfers through other mechanisms (dispositions, intercompany loans).
children.name: Applies to Other Transfers
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 84 (Unknown); KCT Cat 3 Item 4

children.definition: Whether the cap applies to all transfer mechanisms (investments, RPs, dispositions) or only to certain baskets.
children.name: Transfer Means Coverage

children.definition: Protection expressly capping the amount of investment capacity that can be used to transfer assets to unrestricted subsidiaries (LME Protection #4). Per the LME Provision Language, an Envision blocker limits unrestricted subsidiary transfers to specific investment baskets or imposes an aggregate cap on all unrestricted subsidiary investments, and should apply to transfers through any means (restricted payments, investments or otherwise). Weakness: blocker does not apply to all types of transfers (e.g., applies to 'Permitted Investments' and not restricted payments). PC Term Comparison: Envision protection is not universal but some clients push to limit investments in unrestricted subs to certain baskets; not a must-have in UMM/BSLR transactions but more commonly included in CMM/LMM.
children.name: Envision Blocker

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Broader permitted modifications; no operating lease restriction; no sub equity issuance restriction
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Anti-Envision: restrict priming transactions via new-money super-priority debt; require 100% lender consent for lien subordination

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Investments – Investments in Unsubs/JVs

children.definition_source: LME Provision Language protection #4 (Envision specification with sample clause from Blend Labs June 2021 CA); PC Term Comparison neg covs (Envision not universal but pushed by some clients); Review Template row 68 (Envision formulation)
pc_ref: neg covs (Envision not universal but pushed by some clients)

children.definition: Whether the credit agreement contains an explicit prohibition on lien subordination without affected lender consent. Lien subordination creates new senior-priority security interests ahead of existing lenders, altering the collateral recovery waterfall in enforcement scenarios. Distinguished from payment subordination because it governs asset liquidation proceeds rather than ongoing cash flow distributions.
children.name: Block Present

children.definition: Voting threshold required to amend lien priority provisions under the Serta lien subordination blocker, typically all-lender or affected-lender consent to prevent non-pro-rata lien priming transactions.
children.name: Consent Threshold
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 3 Item 15; KCT Cat 4 Item 11

children.definition: Whether the block extends to amendments that have the indirect effect of subordinating lien priority.
children.name: Covers Indirect Subordination
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 3 Item 15; KCT Cat 4 Item 4; KCT Cat 4 Item 11

children.definition: Blocks amendments that would subordinate existing lien priority to new or priming debt without affected lender consent. []
children.name: Lien Subordination Block
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 3 Item 15; KCT Cat 4 Item 4; KCT Cat 4 Item 11

children.definition: Whether the credit agreement contains an explicit prohibition on payment subordination without affected lender consent. Payment subordination reorders debt service priority so new creditors receive cash flow before existing lenders during the performing life of the loan. Distinguished from lien subordination because it diverts ongoing operating cash flows rather than altering collateral recovery priorities upon enforcement.
children.name: Block Present

children.definition: Voting threshold required to amend payment waterfall provisions under the Serta payment subordination blocker, preventing amendments that would subordinate existing lenders' right of payment without adequate consent.
children.name: Consent Threshold

children.definition: Blocks amendments subordinating payment priority (right of payment) without affected lender consent. []
children.name: Payment Subordination Block
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 51 (Payment of fees); KCT Cat 3 Item 15; KCT Cat 4 Item 11

children.definition: Whether the credit agreement includes explicit Serta-style anti-priming language addressing the effect of uptier exchange transactions on existing lender rights and priorities.
children.name: Language Present

children.definition: Whether the 'effect of' language applies to all sacred rights or only specific subordination protections.
children.name: Scope of Application

children.definition: Whether the sacred rights provision includes 'effect of' or 'effect thereof' language extending protections to amendments that indirectly achieve subordination. Key precedent in Wesco/Incora ruling. []
children.name: 'Effect of' Language

children.definition: Whether the credit agreement includes a ratable participation exception within the Serta blocker framework, requiring that any debt exchange or refinancing transaction be offered pro rata to all lenders.
children.name: Exception Present

children.definition: Whether the ratable offer must be on the same terms as the priming debt (absence creates American Tire loophole).
children.name: Same Terms Required

children.definition: Exception permitting priming debt if all lenders are offered ratable participation on the same terms. Risk: 'same terms' may not be required. []
children.name: Ratable Participation Exception

children.definition: Carveout in the Serta blocker for permitted debt baskets, defining which incremental or refinancing debt transactions are exempted from the anti-priming protections and under what conditions.
children.name: Permitted Debt Carveout

children.definition: Carveout in the Serta blocker for debtor-in-possession financing, permitting priming liens in bankruptcy proceedings where DIP financing is necessary for the debtor's continued operations.
children.name: DIP Financing Carveout
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 3 Item 13; Learning Material: DIP FINANCING

children.definition: Exceptions that may undermine Serta protection: permitted debt carveout, DIP financing carveout, closing-date-terms limitation. []
children.name: Permitted Carveouts

children.definition: Serta structures weaponize borrower buyback carve-outs to create super-priority tranches, leaving non-participating lenders structurally subordinated without consent.
children.name: Super-priority creation prevention

children.definition: Protection requiring heightened lender consent (ideally affected-lender consent) for amendments that subordinate the debt in right of lien or payment priority (LME Protection #5). Per the LME Provision Language, a Serta blocker should prohibit subordination of lien and payment priority to other superpriority debt without affected-lender consent, ideally extending to amendments that 'have the effect of' subordinating priority. Frequently contains exceptions where participation in the priming debt is offered ratably to all lenders on the same terms. Common weaknesses: (a) blocker does not cover both lien and payment priority; (b) ratable offer exception lacks 'same terms' requirement; (c) carve-out for debt 'as otherwise permitted' not limited to terms as of the closing date; (d) carves out specific types of permitted priming Indebtedness; (e) DIP carve-out without ratable participation on same terms (American Tire loophole). KCT Category 3 item 15 describes the Serta structure as using borrower buyback provisions to effectuate a debt-for-debt exchange creating 'super priority' lenders without affected lender consent. PC Term Comparison: include strong Serta protection; clients will likely accept offer to participate but must include on same terms (including fees).
children.name: Serta Blocker

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Broader permitted modifications; no operating lease restriction; no sub equity issuance restriction
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Anti-Serta: prohibit uptier transactions via non-pro-rata open market purchases; require sacred-right protection against subordination

children.definition_source: LME Provision Language protection #5 (complete Serta specification with sample clause from RackSpace March 2024 CA); KCT Category 3 item 15 (Serta structure description); PC Term Comparison section 9 (Serta: strong protection required, same terms including fees)

children.definition: Whether the credit agreement includes NYDJ-style pro rata sharing protections requiring that any amendment, refinancing, or exchange transaction be offered ratably to all lenders of the affected class.
children.name: Protection Present
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 3; PC Term Comparison: 2. Article 2 - Call Protection:

children.definition: Voting threshold required to waive the NYDJ pro rata sharing protection, typically all-lender or affected-class consent to prevent selective refinancing that advantages a subset of lenders.
children.name: Consent Threshold

children.definition: Blocks amendments to the pro rata sharing clause that governs equitable distribution of payments and recoveries among lenders.
children.name: Pro Rata Sharing Protection
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 133 (Assignments – open market purchases)

children.definition: Whether the credit agreement includes NYDJ-style payment waterfall protections that prevent amendments altering the distribution priority of payments among secured creditors without adequate consent.
children.name: Protection Present
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 3; PC Term Comparison: 2. Article 2 - Call Protection:

children.definition: Voting threshold required to amend payment waterfall provisions under the NYDJ waterfall protection, designed to prevent selective payment priority manipulation benefiting a lender subset.
children.name: Consent Threshold

children.definition: Blocks amendments to the EoD payment waterfall (order of priorities) that governs distribution of proceeds after acceleration or enforcement.
children.name: Payment Waterfall Protection
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 2; PC Term Comparison: 2. Article 2 - Call Protection:

children.definition: Carve-outs that may weaken NYDJ protection by permitting refinancing, amend-and-extend, or incremental transactions that alter pro rata treatment.
children.name: Refinancing Carveouts
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 152 (Unknown); KCT Cat 3 Item 2

children.definition: Protection requiring heightened lender consent (ideally affected-lender consent) for amendments that modify the pro rata sharing or waterfall provisions (LME Protection #6). Per the LME Provision Language, an NYDJ blocker should prohibit amendments to: (a) the pro rata sharing provision; and (b) both the order of payments and the pro rata sharing of payments in the post-event-of-default waterfall provision, in each case without affected-lender consent. Common weaknesses: (a) not protecting both pro rata sharing and waterfall provisions; (b) not protecting amendments to the waterfall's order of priorities; (c) carve-outs for refinancing amendments, amend-and-extend provisions, and incremental equivalent debt that can be abused when broadly drafted. PC Term Comparison: pro rata payments and sharing/waterfalls must be all-lender or all-affected-lender sacred rights; avoid 'except as otherwise permitted' or 'Subject to mandatory prepayments' type language.
children.name: NYDJ Blocker

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Broader permitted modifications; no operating lease restriction; no sub equity issuance restriction
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Restrictions on: modifications to junior/subordinated debt docs, org doc amendments, burdensome/negative-pledge agreements, accounting/fiscal year changes, passive holdco, contingent obligations, speculative hedging, line of business changes, sub equity issuance, operating leases, Patriot Act/FCPA/OFAC

children.definition_source: LME Provision Language protection #6 (complete NYDJ specification with sample clause from MillerKnoll April 2025 CA); PC Term Comparison section 9 (Sacred Rights: pro rata payments and sharing/waterfalls)

children.definition: Whether subordination requirement applies to intercompany debt incurred under all covenant baskets (strong) or only the intercompany basket (weak).
children.name: Applies Across All Baskets

children.definition: Whether the At Home subordination protection scope extends to guarantees in addition to direct obligations, preventing circumvention through guarantee release or subordination as an alternative to direct debt subordination.
children.name: Includes Guarantees

children.definition: Which intercompany debt instruments must be subordinated: all baskets vs. only intercompany basket, and whether guarantees of nonloan party debt are covered.
children.name: Subordination Scope

children.definition: Whether intercompany debt to nonloan parties must also be unsecured, preventing collateral claims by non-guarantor subsidiaries.
children.name: Unsecured Requirement

children.definition: Extension of liability management protections to cover unrestricted subsidiaries, preventing the borrower from using subsidiary designations to move assets outside the credit agreement's protective perimeter. Inspired by the At Home restructuring, these provisions restrict transactions between restricted and unrestricted subsidiaries that could diminish the collateral or credit support available to the lender group.
children.name: Covers Unrestricted Subs

children.definition: Whether the At Home non-loan-party leakage protection covers non-guarantor restricted subsidiaries, which can receive asset transfers that remain within the restricted group but outside the guarantee and collateral perimeter.
children.name: Covers Nonguarantor Restricted

children.definition: Breadth of nonloan party entities covered by the subordination requirement: unrestricted subs only, nonguarantor restricted subs, or all nonloan party affiliates.
children.name: Nonloan Party Coverage

children.definition: Protection requiring that any intercompany debt incurred under any debt basket that is owed by a loan party to a non-loan-party subsidiary be subordinated to the loans (LME Protection #7). Per the LME Provision Language, this provision is often found at the end of the debt covenant and should require subordination of all intercompany debt incurred by a loan party and owed to a non-loan party (including unrestricted subsidiaries, nonguarantor restricted subsidiaries, or nonrestricted affiliates) under any basket. Must not be confused with a restriction that applies only to the intercompany basket (which would leave other baskets unprotected). PC Term Comparison: require that intercompany debt owed by Loan Parties to non-Loan Parties is subordinated to the PC client debt. This prevents double-dip and pari-plus LME structures where a nonguarantor's intercompany loan to a loan party establishes a pari secured claim.
children.name: At Home Blocker

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Broader permitted modifications; no operating lease restriction; no sub equity issuance restriction
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Restrictions on: modifications to junior/subordinated debt docs, org doc amendments, burdensome/negative-pledge agreements, accounting/fiscal year changes, passive holdco, contingent obligations, speculative hedging, line of business changes, sub equity issuance, operating leases, Patriot Act/FCPA/OFAC

children.definition_source: LME Provision Language protection #7 (At Home specification with sample clause from AMC July 2024 CA); PC Term Comparison neg covs Double Dip section ('Require that intercompany debt owed by Loan Parties to non-Loan Parties is subordinated to the PC Client debt')

children.definition: Whether the voting manipulation blocker is itself included as a sacred right (cannot be removed by majority vote).
children.name: Sacred Right Status

children.definition: Prohibits incurrence of debt for the primary purpose of influencing amendment or consent votes. Addresses the underlying manipulation, not just the voting consequence.
children.name: Incurrence Prohibition

children.definition: Time window around amendment request during which newly issued debt is excluded from voting (e.g., 30/60/90 days).
children.name: Exclusion Period

children.definition: Whether the disenfranchisement extends to debt held by sponsor affiliates or only borrower-group entities.
children.name: Applies to Affiliates

children.definition: Debt issued concurrently with seeking an amendment or consent is excluded from vote calculations, neutralizing the manipulation.
children.name: Disenfranchisement Mechanism

children.definition: Specific restrictions on whether incremental facility debt can vote on amendments to the existing facility terms.
children.name: Incremental Voting Restrictions
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 131 (Unknown); KCT Cat 3 Item 4; LME Provision Language, Restrictions on Issuing New Debt to Influence Voting (Wesco/Incora)

children.definition: Protection restricting the company from manipulating voting thresholds, including by issuing additional voting debt (LME Protection #10). Per the LME Provision Language, a Wesco/Incora blocker should restrict the company from incurring or authorizing additional debt for the primary purpose of influencing voting thresholds. Alternatively, the agreement may disenfranchise any debt issued concurrently with the seeking of any amendment, consent, or waiver. The blocker must be included in the sacred rights to prevent majority creditors from removing it. Potential issues: (a) not including the blocker as a sacred right; (b) only including the blocker as a sacred right (prohibiting amendments that authorize vote-rigging debt) but not prohibiting the actual incurrence of such debt without an amendment (as in Robertshaw). PC Term Comparison: clients currently focused on Incora blockers, pro forma Required Lenders votes, and commitments voting.
children.name: Wesco/Incora Blocker

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Broader permitted modifications; no operating lease restriction; no sub equity issuance restriction
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Restrictions on: modifications to junior/subordinated debt docs, org doc amendments, burdensome/negative-pledge agreements, accounting/fiscal year changes, passive holdco, contingent obligations, speculative hedging, line of business changes, sub equity issuance, operating leases, Patriot Act/FCPA/OFAC

children.definition_source: LME Provision Language protection #10 (Wesco/Incora specification with sample clause from RackSpace March 2024 CA); PC Term Comparison section 9 (Amendments: clients focused on Incora blockers)

children.definition: Block at time of subsidiary designation as unrestricted: unsub must not hold debt recourse to restricted group at time of designation.
children.name: Designation-Time Restriction

children.definition: Whether the ongoing restriction covers liens held by the unsub on restricted group assets, not just debt instruments.
children.name: Includes Liens

children.definition: Whether the unrestricted subsidiary debt holding restriction extends to equity interests in addition to debt instruments, preventing circumvention through equity-linked instruments or convertible securities at unrestricted subsidiaries.
children.name: Includes Equity Interests
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 8; Learning Material: Equity Interests in Unrestricted and Immaterial Subsidiaries

children.definition: Continuing restriction preventing unsubs from acquiring debt or liens recourse to the restricted group after initial designation.
children.name: Ongoing Restriction

children.definition: Prohibits unrestricted subsidiaries from holding debt or liens recourse to the restricted group. LME Provision Language Protection #8: 'A provision that prohibits unrestricted subsidiaries from holding at any time debt or liens that are recourse to the restricted group. This provision often is found in the unrestricted subsidiary definition and/or the unrestricted subsidiary designation provisions.' The blocker should apply both at the time of designation and at any point thereafter. Inherent weakness: it only mitigates double-dip risk at an unsub and not at a nonloan party. DLS Preferred row 92 (Unrestricted Subsidiaries) alternative includes the condition: 'No subsidiary can be designated as an unrestricted subsidiary if: (i) such unrestricted subsidiary has debt that is recourse to a Loan Party.'
children.name: Unsub Debt Holding Restriction

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Broader permitted modifications; no operating lease restriction; no sub equity issuance restriction
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Restrictions on: modifications to junior/subordinated debt docs, org doc amendments, burdensome/negative-pledge agreements, accounting/fiscal year changes, passive holdco, contingent obligations, speculative hedging, line of business changes, sub equity issuance, operating leases, Patriot Act/FCPA/OFAC

children.definition_source: LME Provision Language Protection #8 (unsub debt holding: definition, temporal scope, inherent weakness); DLS Preferred row 92 (unrestricted sub designation condition: no debt recourse to Loan Party)

children.definition: Requires cash-only consideration for borrower or affiliate debt buybacks, preventing non-cash exchange transactions.
children.name: Cash Consideration Requirement
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 97 (Unknown); KCT Cat 1 Item 3

children.definition: Requirement that any open-market debt repurchase be structured as a pro rata offer to all lenders (Dutch auction or similar), preventing selective buybacks that create disparate treatment among lenders of the same class.
children.name: Pro Rata Offer Requirement

children.definition: Requires purchased loans to be immediately cancelled and commitments permanently reduced, preventing reissuance.
children.name: Cancellation Requirement

children.definition: Conditions or restrictions limiting the assignment provisions from being used to effectuate a non-pro-rata LME exchange (LME Protection #9). Per the LME Provision Language, these include requirements such as: assignment to the borrower must be made for cash consideration (preventing non-pro-rata debt-for-debt exchanges through the assignment mechanics). DLS Preferred permits buybacks of term loans through Dutch auctions open to all lenders on a pro rata basis, subject to conditions: (1) no EoD continuing, (2) loans permanently cancelled upon acquisition, (3) no revolving facility proceeds used for purchases. Alternative formulations allow open market purchases on a non-pro-rata basis as well.
children.name: Non-Pro-Rata Purchase Restrictions

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Broader permitted modifications; no operating lease restriction; no sub equity issuance restriction
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Restrictions on: modifications to junior/subordinated debt docs, org doc amendments, burdensome/negative-pledge agreements, accounting/fiscal year changes, passive holdco, contingent obligations, speculative hedging, line of business changes, sub equity issuance, operating leases, Patriot Act/FCPA/OFAC

children.definition_source: LME Provision Language protection #9 (non-pro-rata purchase restrictions with sample clause from RackSpace March 2024 CA); DLS Preferred row 96 (buyback provisions with pro rata Dutch auction requirement)

children.definition: Extensions must be offered ratably to all lenders of the specified tranche, not selectively to favored lenders.
children.name: Pro Rata Extension Requirement
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 3 Item 7; LME Provision Language, Pro Rata Sharing, Waterfall Provisions Included in Sacred Rights (NYDJ)

children.definition: Whether the pro rata extension requirement is itself a sacred right requiring all/affected lender consent to remove.
children.name: Sacred Right Status
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 62 (Right to Appoint Additional Agents)

children.definition: Extended tranche must have the same or junior payment priority as the original tranche, preventing extension as a priming mechanism.
children.name: Payment Priority Constraint

children.definition: Protection against using a credit agreement's amend-and-extend provisions to carry out a non-pro-rata LME exchange (LME Protection #13). Per the LME Provision Language, a Better Health blocker should: (a) require that any loans made under the extension provisions be made on a pro rata basis (the 'Pro Rata Extension Requirement'); and (b) protect that requirement as a sacred right. Additionally, any extended tranche must have the same or more junior payment priority than the specified existing tranche. PC Term Comparison: clients want extension offers to be pro rata; DLS Preferred: extensions permitted with consent of only extending lenders, subject to pro rata offer within the applicable class.
children.name: Better Health Blocker

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Broader permitted modifications; no operating lease restriction; no sub equity issuance restriction
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Restrictions on: modifications to junior/subordinated debt docs, org doc amendments, burdensome/negative-pledge agreements, accounting/fiscal year changes, passive holdco, contingent obligations, speculative hedging, line of business changes, sub equity issuance, operating leases, Patriot Act/FCPA/OFAC

children.definition_source: LME Provision Language protection #13 (Better Health specification with sample clause from private company CA); PC Term Comparison Amend and Extend section ('Would want offers to be pro rata'); DLS Preferred row 17 (Amend and Extend: subject to pro rata offer within applicable class)

children.definition: Scope element testing whether the omni-blocker captures uptier exchange transactions (Serta-style), where a subset of lenders exchange existing loans into new super-priority debt. Uptier exchanges are the most direct form of lender-on-lender violence because they explicitly subordinate non-participating lenders within the same credit facility through a new priority tranche. This is the most commonly covered priming vector.
children.name: Covers Uptier

children.definition: Scope element testing whether the omni-blocker captures non-pro-rata open market purchases or selective debt buybacks that benefit participating lenders at the expense of holdouts. Unlike uptier exchanges that involve structural re-tranching, non-pro-rata transactions operate through selective purchasing in secondary markets, making them harder to detect and requiring specific contractual language to prohibit.
children.name: Covers Non-Pro-Rata

children.definition: Scope element testing whether the omni-blocker extends to indirect methods that achieve priming effects without a direct uptier exchange or non-pro-rata purchase. Circumvention tactics include subsidiary asset transfers (J.Crew trapdoor), collateral releases followed by new secured debt issuance, and lien priority manipulation through covenant amendment. This is the hardest priming vector to draft against because the methods are creative.
children.name: Covers Circumvention

children.definition: The defined scope of 'Priming Financing' or 'Liability Management Transaction' that triggers the omni-blocker. Breadth determines effectiveness.
children.name: Priming Financing Definition

children.definition: Permitted exceptions to the omni-blocker: acquisition financing, pre-existing senior debt, permitted refinancing.
children.name: Omni-Blocker Carveouts
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 3 Item 12; LME Provision Language, Anti-LME Covenant ("Omni-Blocker")

children.definition: Whether the omni-blocker includes a bona fide purpose determination requirement, limiting its scope to transactions lacking legitimate business purpose.
children.name: Bona Fide Purpose Test

children.definition: A comprehensive anti-LME covenant that seeks to prevent all types of liability management exercises (LME Protection #14). Per the LME Provision Language, an omni-blocker should protect against the end (a non-pro-rata LME) as well as the means (the known routes to an LME), helping to protect against both known and unknown forms of LMEs. Sample clause from Getty Images February 2025 CA defines 'Priming Financing/Liability Management Transaction' as any exchange of term loans with new debt 'specifically designed to uptier holders on a non-pro-rata basis into New LMT Debt that is contractually or structurally senior relative to then existing Term Loans,' with enumerated carve-outs for bona fide acquisition financing, debt already contractually/structurally senior, and permitted refinancings.
children.name: Omni-Blocker (Anti-LME Covenant)

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Broader permitted modifications; no operating lease restriction; no sub equity issuance restriction
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Restrictions on: modifications to junior/subordinated debt docs, org doc amendments, burdensome/negative-pledge agreements, accounting/fiscal year changes, passive holdco, contingent obligations, speculative hedging, line of business changes, sub equity issuance, operating leases, Patriot Act/FCPA/OFAC

children.definition_source: LME Provision Language protection #14 (Omni-Blocker specification with sample clause from Getty Images February 2025 CA)

children.definition: Whether the J.Crew blocker is included as a sacred right requiring more than Required Lender consent to modify.
children.name: J.Crew Embedded as Sacred Right
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 69 (Unknown); KCT Cat 1 Item 3; Learning Material: 4) J. Crew Protection in Credit Agreements; LME Provision Language, Restrictions on Material Intellectual Property or Other Asset Leakage to Unsubs (J.Crew)

children.definition: Whether the Envision blocker is included as a sacred right requiring more than Required Lender consent to modify.
children.name: Envision Embedded as Sacred Right

children.definition: Whether the Pluralsight-style non-guarantor transfer blocker is elevated to sacred right status requiring more than Required Lender consent (typically all-lender or affected-lender) for amendment or waiver.
children.name: Pluralsight Embedded as Sacred Right

children.definition: Whether additional LME blockers beyond the four named protections (J.Crew, Chewy, Serta, Envision) are embedded as sacred rights requiring heightened consent thresholds for amendment or waiver.
children.name: Other Blockers Embedded
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 84 (Unknown); KCT Cat 1 Item 2

children.definition: Elevation of LME blockers (J.Crew, Envision, Pluralsight, At Home, etc.) to sacred rights requiring affected/all lender consent to modify. LME Provision Language Protection #12: 'In credit agreements, it is common for Serta and NYDJ blockers to be included as sacred rights. Sometimes (usually in post-LME credit agreements), other LME blockers also are included as sacred rights. This gives lenders additional protection, because only affected lender consent can remove the blockers.' Sample from AMC July 2024: sacred rights include prohibition on amendments that would 'permit any Subsidiary to be designated as an "unrestricted Subsidiary" or permit the transfer of any assets to "unrestricted Subsidiaries"' without 'written consent of each Lender.' PC Term Comparison: 'Include all other customary sacred rights protections.'
children.name: Non-Serta/NYDJ Blockers in Sacred Rights

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Broader permitted modifications; no operating lease restriction; no sub equity issuance restriction
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Restrictions on: modifications to junior/subordinated debt docs, org doc amendments, burdensome/negative-pledge agreements, accounting/fiscal year changes, passive holdco, contingent obligations, speculative hedging, line of business changes, sub equity issuance, operating leases, Patriot Act/FCPA/OFAC

children.definition_source: LME Provision Language Protection #12 (non-Serta/NYDJ blockers as sacred rights; AMC July 2024 sample clause); PC Term Comparison Amendments section line 497 ('Include all other customary sacred rights protections')

children.definition: Category of protections against value leakage through transfers to unrestricted or nonguarantor subsidiaries. Includes J.Crew, Pluralsight, Envision.
children.name: Drop-Down LME Protections
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 8; LME Provision Language, Protections Against Using a Credit Agreement's Amend-and-Extend Provisions to Carry Out a Non-Pro-Rata LME Exchange (Better Health)

children.definition: Category of protections against subordination of existing debt through amendment mechanics. Includes Serta, NYDJ, Wesco/Incora.
children.name: Uptier LME Protections

children.definition: Category of protections against claim multiplication through intercompany debt and structural subordination. Includes At Home blocker.
children.name: Double-Dip / Pari-Plus Protections
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 71 (Unknown); KCT Cat 2 Item 1

children.definition: Restrictions on transactions between borrower group and sponsor/management affiliates that could facilitate LME-adjacent value extraction. Management fee caps, arms-length requirements.
children.name: Sponsor Affiliate Transaction Controls
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 124 (Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates –)

children.definition: Historical progression of LME protections: pre-2016 (basic DQ lists), 2016-2019 (J.Crew watershed, 87.1% adoption), 2020+ (Chewy/Serta era, 93.5% adoption speed record).
children.name: Protection Evolution Timeline

children.definition: Overarching LME awareness and protection architecture. LME Provision Language organizes 14 protections across four categories: (1) Drop-Down (J.Crew #1, Chewy #2, Pluralsight #3, Envision #4) -- against asset leakage to unrestricted or nonguarantor subsidiaries; (2) Uptier (Serta #5, NYDJ #6) -- against lien/payment subordination and pro-rata/waterfall modifications; (3) Double-Dip/Pari-Plus (At Home #7, Unsub Debt #8) -- against intercompany loan schemes creating duplicative claims; (4) General (Non-Pro-Rata Purchase #9, Wesco/Incora #10, Effect-of Language #11, Sacred Rights Embedding #12, Better Health #13, Omni-Blocker #14). PC Term Comparison notes 'currently with greater emphasis on tightening baskets that avoid leakage and present LME risk.'
children.name: General LME Framework

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Broader permitted modifications; no operating lease restriction; no sub equity issuance restriction
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Restrictions on: modifications to junior/subordinated debt docs, org doc amendments, burdensome/negative-pledge agreements, accounting/fiscal year changes, passive holdco, contingent obligations, speculative hedging, line of business changes, sub equity issuance, operating leases, Patriot Act/FCPA/OFAC

children.definition_source: LME Provision Language (complete 14-protection framework across 4 categories); PC Term Comparison Negative Covenants General Note ('greater emphasis on tightening baskets that avoid leakage and present LME risk')
pc_ref: Negative Covenants General Note ('greater emphasis on tightening baskets that avoid leakage and present LME risk')

definition: Protections against liability management exercises (LMEs) -- transactions that subordinate, strip, or dilute existing lenders' credit position without their individual consent. The LME Provision Language catalogs 14 named protections organized under 4 categories: Category 1 (Drop-Down) protects against moving material assets to unrestricted or nonguarantor subsidiaries and monetizing them through structurally senior debt (J.Crew/Pluralsight/Envision blockers, Chewy automatic release restrictions); Category 2 (Uptier) protects against subordination of liens or payment priority through majority-consent amendments (Serta/NYDJ blockers); Category 3 (Double-Dip/Pari-Plus) protects against intercompany loan structures that create duplicative claims (At Home subordination, unsub debt holding restrictions); Category 4 (General) provides broader protections including non-pro-rata purchase restrictions, Wesco/Incora voting manipulation restrictions, 'effect of' language, non-Serta/NYDJ blockers as sacred rights, Better Health pro rata extension requirements, and the Omni-Blocker anti-LME covenant.
name: LME Protections
definition_source: LME Provision Language (complete document: 14 protections across 4 categories with definitions, drafting considerations, common weaknesses, and sample clauses); PC Term Comparison section 5 neg covs (Chewy, J.Crew, Envision, double dip); KCT Category 3 item 15 (Serta structure)
